title: Testing the Water
subtitle: Britain's first lifeguards' training centre has just opened. Matt Seaton went to find out what the course was like.

cards.text: The scene: a sun-drenched beach. Suddenly, a girl in a red swimming costume comes running along the beach towards me. Do I look as if I need rescuing? Sadly, not. She is busy making the German version of Baywatch, an American TV programme about lifeguards, which is being filmed in Majorca. One week later, the scene is still a sun-drenched beach, but now I'm in Cornwall, England. This time, I'm not on holiday, but on a lifeguard's course. With any luck, and lots of physically demanding work, in just a few days I will be a fully qualified, much-admired lifeguard. As I was expecting rain and a howling gale, this was April - I was slightly surprised by the brilliant sunshine. Even so, I did not look forward to the prospect of going into the chilly ocean.

cards.text: I checked in at the National Lifeguard Training Centre, checked my size and pulled a wetsuit out of the rack, the kind that's tight as a second skin. Then the double doors led onto the beach, where the shingle bit my feet through the wetsuit boots. Even so, I did not look forward to the prospect of going into the chilly ocean. 300m may not sound much, but after a short run and a dive through the first big wave...

cards.text: 300m may not sound much, but after a short run and a dive through the first big wave... The feeling is somewhere between fear and exhilaration when you realize you still have most of your swim ahead of you.

cards.highlight: The feeling is somewhere between fear and exhilaration

cards.text: Nothing, however, prepares you for the cold. It smacks you in the face, making your whole skull ache. The surfers have a nice phrase for it: 'ice-cream head'. The swimming, too, was fine—tough. George Alecock, who helps run the course, explained: 'People who think being a lifeguard is fun, and sporty, but it's not until you know your stuff.' A surprising amount of that 'stuff' is knowing how to cope with the sea itself—how to read the waves and currents, and above all, how to deal with the cold.

cards.text: The problem is that very few of us actually grasp the experience and sense of the sea, so most will simply jump in, and then use all their energy swimming against the waves and currents instead of going with them. Swimmers can easily drown in them.

They are the biggest cause of lifeguards' problems.
cards.highlight: Swimmers can easily drown in them

cards.text: By late afternoon, it looked as if I was going to be spared the final water training session. Then Griffiths, the instructor, announced that it was cancelled... I have to say that Griffiths was very sensible about it.
